Harry was looking for help with a particularly difficult spell. After all, this year's exams would be crucial in deciding whether he possessed the skill, power, and dedication to become an Auror.

He checked the library first, always a safe bet for Hermione, but this time she wasn't there. She wasn't in the common room, either, and Harry was about to give up, when he recalled the Marauder's Map. Finding an empty table he laid it out, and set about scanning it for Hermione's name and location. Magic came a poor second to Google Maps in some respects Harry thought. The flexible nature of the castle architecture made the task even harder. But he finally spotted her, in alone in an isolated part of the castle. Watching for a short while he confirmed it was her. The marker wasn't moving, and he guessed she was lost in a good book... a good text book, probably.

It would take ten minutes to walk that far, but 'Mischief Managed', he refolded the map and tucked it away. He spotted Draco as he made his way through the castle, but Draco didn't spot him, so he avoided him.

As he climbed the last set of stairs, Harry was short of breath, as he approached his friend. His shoes made no noise as he spotted her. She was sitting with her back to the door, in the middle of the floor and from her gestures stirring a cauldron.

It was clear that she didn't know he was there. She was talking quietly to herself, he was very tempted to listen, but afraid that she'd say something she didn't want overheard.

So Harry weighed up his options, and decided to startle her.

Stopping about two feet from her back, he could smell the shampoo in her hair, and hear her humming a tune as she mixed the pink liquid in her cauldron. She carefully dipped a tiny potion phial into the mix and took a sample.

"Hermione." he said loudly, but without shouting.

She jumped out of her skin. Hermione thrashed about until she got her feet under her, then she whirled about to face Harry.

The cauldron rang, as her shoes clanged against it, her face was furious. Harry put on his best, 'It was only a joke' face, and raised his hands to signal his surrender.

12533122221.content:
Rita Skeeter was at her desk at the Daily Prophet when she was hit by the revelation. She was getting old, and her contacts were getting old. The magical journalism business was cut throat enough, without the problems of being behind, too far behind, with the headlines.

It was clear that a new generation of wizards was rising, and rising fast.

There were a host of students at Hogwarts, that were likely to shape the future, and take on considerable power in the coming days, months and years. She ground her teeth at her missteps during the Tri-wizard tournament. She'd dismissed them as children, treating them with undisguised contempt.

She no longer thought of Harry Potter as 'the Boy who lived', a lucky child who survived an attack by the Dark Lord, and was she no longer dismissed him as lacking talent. Her experience had cautioned her against inherited magic superiority. A view she never voiced, but she knew parentage was no guarantee for a good wizard.

A few years ago, she had had to spike a story. Too much pressure from above, she'd 'discovered' Draco Malfoy's magical rating, his inherent abilities. His magical potential was barely more than a squib. She'd presented her evidence and story to her editor, eager to please, and zealous for a by-line.

It was meticulously researched, and corroborated. She rubbed her hands in anticipation, but when the editor had returned to her desk. Her original notes were heavily annotated. She was told in no uncertain terms to lose the story. The Prophet would never publish it, and she'd be very unwise to try and sell it elsewhere.

Her own magic skills were quite formidable, as well as being an unregistered animagus, she had incredible discovery magical powers. She analysed her own notes. The pages took on a glow that came from her own Quick Quills, with a gesture to the side, she swept those away.

The other magical touches became clearer. The pages were much dimmer, and she recognised her editor's magic, another gesture and those were swept away too.

What remained was the touch of a powerful magic user. He had notes had been scried, someone was looking for the source of her work. The people who had talked to her. A scowl crossed her face, her editor had undermined a basic principle of journalism. Hell, it was true even of muggle journalism, you don't reveal your sources.

She pulled apart the traces of the magic on her notes. Detecting the alignment, and preferences of the user. It confirmed her suspicions, the notes, HER notes had been handed over to a Malfoy. Probably Lucius, but Narcissa was not without her methods, and was fierce in the defence of her child.

Even now, she found herself grinding her teeth. The protection that the powerful had, was unjust. She hated the privilege that came easily to some. Controlling her anger, she wondered if that had coloured her judgement, her actions in the past.

She wrote off a note, an apology, to Harry Potter. It was sincere, and she realised that she had to mend bridges to the current generation. She asked for an audience... a meeting, a chance to set the record straight.

She gave it to her owl, and set him off on the long journey to Scotland, and the castle.

The reply came back the next day. It was better than she'd hoped. Harry had agreed to meet her in Hogsmeade, his note was polite, and well-written. She had a good eye for these things, and thought he'd make a good journalist, or writer if he wanted to turn his skills in that direction.

There was a time and a location.

The Tea shop in the High Street in two days time.

125331222213.content:
Harry, Ron and Hermione were sharing a large pot of tea. Hermione and Harry rather enjoying it. While Ron looked more like he was involved in some arcane ceremony. Rita went a little closer. She was still nervous, and not surprised that Harry had brought along some company... some witnesses.

Her instincts kept her on edge. But that didn't stop her from being covered with an upturned jar. She scuttled about, but was unable to escape. Harry looked down on her. His face distorted through the glass. But his face was triumphant, and unhappy. He slide a postcard underneath. It was slow enough, that she didn't risk getting her spindly legs broken.

She fell to the bottom, when he up-ended the bottle. With a clap, the lid was put in place, and a twist was enough to secure it.

Her antennae twitched as she raced around the jar. The sides were too slick to climb, but at least there were some air holes in the top.

Hermione took the container from Harry's hands and put it on the table out of reach.

"See. I told you we could make our own Marauder's Map for Hogsmeade."

"I didn't say we couldn't. I just said maybe we shouldn't."

"Well, it turned out useful here and now."

She turned towards the trapped little bug, "It is useful, isn't it."

Tapping the glass, the effect was deafening inside the little jar. Hermione slid her finger down the side until she tapped the map, spread across the tabletop.

Rita saw a plan of Hogsmeade, an active map, with the moving position of the various wizards and witches marked on it. Their little feet leaving trails as they passed.

Her eyes were drawn to the end of Hermione's finger. The position of the three friends was marked. But more revealing, she was still present. If an insect's shoulders could drop, they would have dropped here. Rita couldn't even deny she was there.

Harry points to a quieter corner of the Tea-room. "If you get the map, we can talk privately."

It was darker in the corner, a feature that appealed to a number of customers.

"I'm... We're investigating animagi." Harry told her.

Ron sat down, still tucking the map away. Hermione looked around before joining the boys. The three students drew absolutely no attention.

"You could have just come and talked to us." Ron added. "But no. You had to spy first, didn't you?"

Hermione settled Ron with a hand, or rather distracted him from Rita.

"You probably know ... or suspect that my father was an animagus."

The beetle gave a quick tilt of the head. Harry took that to mean yes. It didn't really matter. "His friends were also animagi."

Rita was surprised. Her information was good on James Potter and his friends, so this was a revelation.

"I'm working... We're working on a potion, and it requires some animagus DNA., some of your hair."

The beetle shifted agitatedly. Clearly unwilling to submit.

"If you prefer, I could use an antenna. And when you return to human form... when we allow you back into human form, you'll just have to see how you manage."

The bug was powerless to resist. Her greatest gift as an animagus was stealth. A bug was ignored, it lacked the intimidation of a wolf, or the cuddliness of a cat.

"I appreciate that you might want to renege on our little deal. But I must caution you against that. I can keep you in that jar and feed you on scraps for a very long time. And I think you know what happens when a wizard or witch spends too long in their animal form."

Rita was rather a vain woman, even if she didn't like to admit it. She preferred to think of her attraction coming from her talent, her writing skills.

Harry shook the jar, and took the lid off while she was still bouncing from side to side.

"I'm thinking of a binding promise. That you will give us a lock of your hair, and also that you will never knowingly write lies about people... ever again."

As Rita settled herself, she found the jar upended and she was sitting on Harry Potter's hand.

"You'll glow when you agree to be bound by the promise."

Ron looked on seemingly enjoying the spectacle. Hermione was less happy about the situation. However, neither of the friends was ready to interfere. This was well earned on Rita's part. Her poisonous words had made life at Hogwarts a living hell.

Harry watches at the bug scampered about agitatedly, before surrendering. She turned to face Harry, and then she glowed, as Rita made the binding promise.

"I know you think you've been hard done by here. But you should remember, that you could have come openly, instead of spying on us."

Harry placed the jar on an empty seat, before unwinding the glass jar and lifting it clear. His hand was barely out of the way, as Rita changed back into her human form. Her mouth hinted at a snarl, while her eyes darted about in fear.

It took her a moment to settle down. She took a pair of nail scissors from her bag, and snipped at her fringe before passing the lock to Harry.

"Thank you." he said with a tilt of his head.

Rita hated when she was outmanoeuvred. But she had to admit that Harry wasn't merely a child born to unfortunate parents. He had genuine magical skill, and intelligence. Smoothing imaginary wrinkles from her skirt, she tried to bring things back on track.

"Sorry, Harry. You are right." Her words were painfully spoken, and carried little emotion.

Ron didn't believe her. While Harry was more familiar with painful admissions.

She leaned back in her chair, and addressed them all.

"I know we didn't get off to the best of starts... some journalistic advantages are hard to resist. But I wanted to make peace."

"You've not convinced me that you are a changed individual. But I await your next few columns with interest. If I see that you haven't tried to twist your promise, then we can work to build our trust."

Rita weighed up his words. It was a wasted journey, but should still hold promise. She decided to entrust the three students with her attempt to release Draco's less than impressive magic record.

The three friends shared an look. Draco was dangerous, treacherous and intelligent, but when it came to magic he was more bluster than reality. Using his family as intimidation.

Harry decided to make his own overture.

"If we are successful with this potion, then I will come to you with all the details, and that's a promise."

Ron shrugged, while Hermione was a little put out, at Harry giving that snippet away.

Rita was happy with the conclusion, and shook their hands before leaving. If she were quick she could catch the next train south.

She thanked them sincerely, and the friends smiled at her. Ron more so as she left the tea-room.

125331222213211.content:
Back at the castle the three friends, assembled the spell components. Rita's lock of hair being added to the 3 strands of Professor McGonagall's hair. Harry brought out a few coarse hairs from Sirius's fur.

Harry restrained a smile, as Ron was fascinated not by the ingredients but by the inventiveness of muggles. A cellophane bag, with a seal at the top. Hermione gave Harry a look, while Ron was sealing and unsealing the strip at the top. They'd both learned long ago, not to take the mickey.

As a present, Harry had sent Arthur Weasley a pack of empty bags. Ron hadn't stopped talking about how excited his father had been to receive them. Although it did invite a whole series of questions about other muggle artifacts that had caught his interest. Harry had had to request pictures to find out what he was talking about. He was endlessly fascinated with TV remotes... How did they work without magic?

With an effort Harry brought his concentration back to the task in hand. Putting them each in separate little baggies, he tucked them away.

"I think we should keep looking for something of your father's?" Hermione urged.

"We already have three different strands of DNA, different animals. Are you sure we need a fourth?"

Harry was eager to start work on the potion. There was also the fact that he didn't like this focus on his dead father. James had obviously loved his time at Hogwarts, and Harry felt the loss more intensely whenever his name came up. He also felt that it was personal and something he didn't want to share.

"We could try the old Quidditch supplies, if we check the snitch, and the bludgers, there might be some DNAs on that?" Ron said.

The Rivelio parentis spell to scan for DNA was something that Hermione had created. Something she was protective of, too. She'd confided in Harry that she was worried, that some wizards might abuse it. That it could be used to prove the difference between full-blood wizards, and others with muggle parents, or mixed muggle-wizard parents.

Ron liked the spell, but his knowledge of DNA was uncertain at best. The red hair of Weasley's was the simplest way she explained it to him. Hermione loved Ron, and knew he wasn't stupid. But there were certain things that were alien to him. That anyone else might find more intuitive.

She pecked Ron on the cheek, "Good idea."

They both blushed, and Harry studiously paid attention to the strands of hair.

Ron's brothers had reported finding an old cache of school equipment high up in the second tallest tower of the castle. There had to be something there. Harry was hopeful, as the Captain he would have been awarded the match balls.

Harry tried not to think of the possibility that he'd taken them home to Godric's Hollow. The idea that that was something else lost from Harry past made him shudder.

Harry was first into the loft, his wand lighting the way. Ron followed, and Hermione brought up the rear.

Rivelio Parentis.

Harry cast the spell, and the light from the tip of his wand flickered and shifted. Hermione followed, and Ron spoke at the same time. Both touched their wands against the bare skin on the back of Harry's hand. They weren't looking for Weasley or Granger artifacts after all.

Lumos Maximus.

The light flared as Harry's wand grew to a blinding whiteness. It illuminated the whole room. The room was much bigger than it appeared on the outside, much like the Room of Requirement. Ron's groan was louder than he intended.

The three friends split up, and started working through the various boxes for anything that might have a stray hair from James Potter.

An hour of intense searching later, and the three were covered head to toe in dust. Beyond hearing Ron squeal whenever he thought he saw a spider they discovered nothing. Nothing was giving off the pale blue glow that would confirm James Potter's DNA.

125331222213211221.content:
Harry carefully takes one hair from each of his baggies. It's a fiddly job, but he slowly braids them together.

"Almost ready?" Ron asks.

Harry stares intently at the braided hairs. McGonagall, Skeeter, Black.

Despite his planning and preparation, he knew this was the moment. He grunted agreement to Ron, and gave the slightest of nods.

Ron took a sample of the potion, into a test tube and offered it to Harry. He had to steady his hand as he took it. Ron moved the cauldron back out of the way.

"How much space should I clear?" he asked half joking.

"I mean, do you want to be a big dog like Sirius, strong and intimidating. Or something more subtle like Rita's form?"

Harry didn't answer, but he released his pinched fingers, and the hairs dropped into the tube.

A tiny cloud shot up from the tube, and the mixture shifted in colour and consistency. The three samples were not settling well in the brew. It became violently purple, then just as suddenly shocking pink, and again shifted to emerald green.

"Are you ready for your part... are you ready with the incantation." Harry's eyes darted over to Ron an unfamiliar harshness visible in his stare.

Ron nodded, already his lips were moving silently, as he rehearsed the spell in preparation.

Harry needed to lighten the mood, "You know I've always been undernourished, and considered weak. So I thought something with clear strength and power... Something that ... Well, a horse." he looked over to Ron, then winked, "Although I always found Norbert to be an appealing form."

But she managed to push down her frustration, that perfect skin, that natural grace.

"Harry." she said, half angrily, half disbelieving.

Hogwarts was still mourning the loss of Dumbledore, and everyone was telling their favourite stories of the Headmaster. Sometimes it was a small act of kindness, a sweet offered at a timely moment. For others it was sage word of advice that helped them make a choice with a difficult decision. Harry was staying away from large crowds, there were too many painful... too many fresh memories... Too many people asking him for his favourite memory of Dumbledore. He even made the effort to escape the comforting words of Ron and Hermione. They meant well, and obviously they too were feeling the loss. But he needed some time to be alone.

That was how Harry came to be walking through a less explored part of the castle. Seeing the size of some of the cobwebs he was sure that Ron's eyes would have been darting around nervously. His steps faltered, as he walked passed a door. It didn't belong there, it just didn't fit with the shape of the corridor, and even in his distracted mood, he was sure it wasn't there a few moments ago.

It had to be the Room of Requirement, he wasn't sure quite what thoughts or desires had summoned it up. But Harry wasn't about to ignore it. He was mildly disappointed when the door didn't creak as he pushed it open. The heavy oak swinging aside smoothly if slowly.

Taking one last look to either side; nobody there. Harry entered and closed the door behind him.

He just wanted a quick look at his family. Telling himself, he had kept his promise to Dumbledore... He hadn't sought it out... But when it was near enough to touch, Harry sighed... it was a different mirror.

Pulling the dust sheet away, it slid down the glass and slithered onto the floor, forming a loose pile around Harry's feet.

There was writing around the frame of the mirror, and Harry ran his fingers over them just enjoying the texture. When he looked at his reflection he was disappointed. It was simply himself, and the rather unkempt room behind him.

Twisting this way and that, he tried to see any magical qualities in the glass. It was only when he leaned in close, to examine his face that he saw anything. The scar was still there... the glasses were still there... but... his in the mirror his hair was tidier.

He stood back upright as he tried to work out the purpose of the mirror. Was it meant to flatter the owner... or to inspire them to better present themselves... or was it instructing him...

Perhaps Hermione would be better able to work out it's purpose, or Ron would see something different. In either case, Harry wanted to consult with his friends, if he found this room again... and if he didn't no harm done.

Harry almost stumbled into the mirror with his feet caught in the dustcloth at his feet. But found his balance before the worst happened. He shook his head at his reflection and carefully stepped out of the tangled cloth.

Something about the reflection was different... again.

If he hadn't shaken his head he might not have noticed. His reflection had longer hair, it was just short of his shoulders, and even as he looked it took on a tidier aspect.

Shifting from a chestnut mess, reminding him vaguely of a lion's mane. It shifted into a tidier curls... similar to Hermione's but shorter.

Running a hand over his head, he confirmed that the reflection wasn't real. It looked realistic, but Harry's hair simply wasn't that long.

Frankly it was starting to freak Harry out. The changes ... and not knowing the nature of the mirror ... well ... both brought their concerns. The mirror could be a Slytherin artifact... But Harry didn't want to just flee because he was afraid. That wasn't a Gryffindor characteristic. Courage was feeling the fear and still doing the right thing... He'd heard that somewhere.

There's a heavy low creak from behind you, "Harry! You in here?", it's Hermione.

"Yes... Over here."

Unfortunately, Harry's feet had become entangled in the cloth. He lost his balance and crashed towards the mirror. He yelped as he felt his ass hit the mirror. Everything tilted wildly as the wooden frame creaked. With a wooden -crack- the hinge broke, and Harry and the mirror crashed ass backwards onto the floor.

For Harry it happened in slow motion. Like a dizzying out of body experience. As he fell, the world stopped moving, and time reversed. Before his eyes, he saw himself walking backwards out of the room. His sense of balance told him he was still falling. But his view unwound further into the past, to the first meal in the Grand Hall. That flickered away in an instant, and Harry saw himself at the Train station trying desperately to figure out how to get to Platform 9 3/4.

The scene flickered again, and he was in a dark, dank room. Spotting a friendly face, he wanted to weep for joy. But no words came out his lips. He was simply a mute passenger on his journey into the past. Unable to express himself, as Hagrid said, "You're a Wizard, Harry."

A faded outline of the real world intruded into Harry vision, as the scene shifted again. This time, to one of Dudley's birthdays, there were five candles on the cake, and as Harry caught his reflection, the misery was already as clear on his face, as his youth.

There was a flurry of owls, as the scene shifted. Harry was wrapped up, warm and cosy. He looked up into the massive face of Albus Dumbledore, and Professor McGonagall. Behind them, towering over them, Hagrid his face wet with tears...

"Dead...", he sobbed, blowing his nose loudly on his handkerchief. It looked big enough to be a towel, or even a blanket at his own diminutive size.

He held out one tiny hand, to try to hold onto the headmaster, but he just scraped his pudgy digits over Dumbledore's nose.

As the scene shifted again, Harry knew there wasn't long to go. Either he'd simply vanish, or be forced to face his own nightmare memories. Even as the realisation struck, he found himself sitting in a crib.

"Take them, Lily... Take them and run..." he felt his throat tighten at the sound of his father's voice.

Outside the door, there was sickening green flash, and a scream. A death scream. Harry knew his father was dead.

Lily entered, her hair was wild, and her eyes glittering green and fired with passion.

But something was off, something was different. His crib was in the wrong place, when he looked over to where it was meant to be, he saw it. There was another crib there. An identical infant sat in his pale blue romper suit, he was crying at the noise. He was still struggling to work out what was going on.

She bent into the crib, and picking him up she hugged him to her chest. "He'll never harm you.... he'll never harm either of you." she swore with passion.

But Voldemort was already behind her, his wand pointing steadily into her back.

"Avada Kadavra."

Sickly green lightning shot forth, and rippled and roared around their hugging bodies. With a shriek, Lily and Harry Potter died in each other's embrace.

As Voldemort tried to pull his wand back, it resisted. The vile green lightning leapt from their bodies, and wrapped itself around the Dark Lord. It was his turn to shriek in pain and denial, as the magic backfired and killed him utterly.

From behind the crib bars, Harry watched still unsure what was happening, still not sure if this was a dream, a nightmare or the actual events... and why they were now different.

He was still in shock, as Hagrid crashed into the room. Literally shattering the frame, as he entered the room. His face fell, as he saw the bodies on the floor. His foot crashed down into the corpse of Voldemort, turning his broken spine to dust. Hagrid's anger fled, and his tenderness returned, as he examined Lily and Harry. But it was already too late. Their lives were extinguished.

A wail ripped itself from Harry's lung, he felt his powerlessness vanish, and a cry rip from his soul.

Hagrid heard it, and a smile split his face.

"I'll keep you safe.... At least, I can keep you safe, little Harriet."

Harry felt himself being lifted in powerful, but tender hands, safe and secure. He was carried to Hagrid's bike. With a kick, the engine started, and they were airborne.

Time flickered, and the scene shifted. He was back on the Dursley's doorstep, still wrapped in the blanket, and his romper suit. Hagrid was sobbing, McGonagall's eyes were wet with tears, and the Headmaster was struggling.

"He was already dead." his voice was distant and cold, "Voldemort was already dead."

"I ... I couldn't save them... I tried..." Hagrid's voice quavered and broke.

He took time to gather his thoughts. His mouth opened and closed several times, but no words came out.

Professor Dumbledore put a steadying hand on his shoulder.

"You saved Harriet... You saved her..."

"Her?" Harry thought. He wasn't able to check. Time flickered, and the scene shifted.

It was Dudley's ninth birthday, and Harriet was passing him a simple present in a white box with a pink ribbon. "Oh Shit." was the thought racing through her head, as Dudley snatched it from her open hands.

Time flickered and flashed, Harry barely noticed.

Until with a crash, Harry returned to the here and now. Sitting up, she saw Hermione leaning in to offer her hand.

"Come on Harriet, just make sure you don't cut yourself."

Extending his hand, Harry saw that once again Hermione was right. His hand was her hand. Slender and feminine, it disappeared into the frilly cuffs of her blouse.

Getting to her feet, she gave a shimmy to shake loose the shards of mirror she felt sticking to the back of her uniform.

A large wicker hamper catches Harry's eye, the edge of a cloak hangs over the edge untidily.

Harry looks around, embarrassed by the thought entering his mind. He rummages through until he finds what he was looking for. He finds a cloak, and slides it into place. Stealing another glance, he's still alone, he spots a mirror and goes over to check out his reflection. The cloak is a little tight on his shoulders, but it's a base impulse.

He runs his fingers over the silver and green serpent embossed on the edge of cloak.

The questions he'd asked himself as he thought about the Sorting Hat. He knew he was in the right house, but that didn't satisfy him entirely. Perhaps as a Slytherin, he'd be more able to vanquish Voldemort.... or as a Ravenclaw, he'd have found a wiser solution to the return of the Dark Lord.

Startled at his absent minded gestures, Harry snatched his fingers away from the serpent. It's quite luxurious too, with a satin lining in forest green. Pulling it closed he found a name tag stitched inside.

'Hestia Carrow'

The name rang a bell. Oh, Yes. From the Slug Club. There was a Slytherin girl there with that name. This was probably her mother's cloak. She looked to be a bit of cold fish. But he'd thought the same of Hermione at first. Besides she was well spoken and held her own in any discussions at the club.

More came back to Harry as he thought about the club and Hestia. She'd had a twin sister... F..-something... Flora. That was it Flora. Wouldn't he still be himself, if he were in Slytherin. If he were friends with the Carrow's rather than the Weasley. Surely a house couldn't change a person. Harry didn't want to dismiss all Slytherin, just because Draco was a .... Draco was Draco. A pipsqueak upstart with delusions.

Realising he'd almost walked into the mirror. He drew himself up to his full height and struck a Slytherin-y pose. Putting a sneer on his face, and an arrogance in his stance.

The reflection isn't what Harry expected at all. There were hints of the Carrow sisters in the image, but it didn't look like them. He was entranced by the image, perhaps it was their mother when she was a student. But she had piercing green eyes, and the sisters were blue eyed. He recalled Hermione nudging him, telling him not to stare.

She was a beautiful girl, and as Harry absently brushes his hair aside, he spots his reflection has the same scar. The pensive look is familiar too. He wasn't sure what to think when he thought again about finding herself beautiful. But the reflection blushed, so Harry imagined he was too.

She mimicked his moves, like a true reflection. He ran his hands down his side and she did too. With a wicked thought, Harry cupped his imaginary bosom. Lifting and squeezing the girls. He felt nothing in his hands, although his reflection was again blushing. It was an odd pose for this, but he thought that the girl was rather well endowed.

He shook his head, and allowed his hands to fall limply away. Again the mirror mirrored.

Harry scanned the frame for writing. He remembered there was a clue carved in the frame of the mirror or Erised.

The palm of his hand brushed against the surface, Harry recoiled. It wasn't chilly like glass or metal. It was warm, the warmth of human flesh.

He was drawn to touch the glass again. Reaching out his hand, he stopped half an inch from it. Then his nerves on edge, he gently tapped on the glass, and snatched his hand back. It rippled like a pond. The ripples vanished at the frame. This time, it had had a texture, it wasn't just warm, it had felt coarse... like skin.

Harry took a deep breath and calmed himself. It was a magic mirror, he wasn't sure what it was showing him. Perhaps a world where he'd been born a girl, a world where he'd been slow to object when the Sorting Hat had suggested Slytherin as his... -er- her house.

Harry scowled at his reflection, maybe he was blaming the wrong thing. It might be the cloak that was enchanted, he might truly be female, and it's only his memories that tell him what he expects.

In any case, if it were dangerous then Dumbledore would have kept it's location more secure or destroyed the item.

He decided the quickest way to settle his nerves was like ripping off a plaster, or facing cold water. Slapping his hand flat onto the glass, the frame rocked with the force of the blow, giving him a glimpse of the ceiling as it almost fell over backwards. But it's weight pulled it back forwards, and gave his hand a slap.

He high-fived his reflection.

That was when things became weird. Harry felt his fingers become wrapped in those of his reflection. Instantly his gaze shot to his hand, semi-transparent fingers were woven around his own. They were more slender than his, and the nails were glazed in glossy crimson.

He tried to break free, twist his hand loose. There was a wrenching, and Harry was pulled forward. His hand vanished beneath the surface of the glass. His reflections face was twisted in victory. Her face a grinning mask. Her hand vanishing at the same point. But you still felt her fingers woven together with yours. A second chilly hand gripped your forearm, and Harry was wrenched forward again. This time up to his shoulder. He scrabbled to break free, flailing wildly afraid to grab the frame with his free hand.

Without a firm grip, Harry was powerless to resist, with a final pull. Harry stumbled across the threshold of the mirror.

A chill raced across his skin as he passed. But that was nothing compared to his other shock.

Looking back out the mirror, Harry saw his body blowing him a kiss before turning and walking away. Harry tried to follow, but the glass was simply a wall to him. Beating his fist on the glass had no effect. Harry watched as he spoke some words, at least his lips moved, but he heard nothing emerge.

Harry felt his chest shift as he battered again and again against the barrier. Looking down, Harry spotted that now he was female. Not overly endowed like the witches in Ron's Magazine.

Although Harry did fantasise about some of them in 'the Golden Snatch'.

Reaching slimmer hands downwards, Harry confirmed that she was fully female. She recoiled when she did confirm it. Her hands flying away like they'd received an electric shock.

She turned around to examine her mirror universe.

Drawn to a plain box, Harry opened it to see a piece of ornate jewellery. With a large blue stone embedded in a web of silver. Initially he thought it was a necklace, big enough to draw admiring eyes, to a suitably displayed cleavage.

It was only when he spotted the Eagle's head atop the gem, that he then recognised the web, as a pair of wings, and knew it was a crown. As he stroked the soft fabric of the box, he saw it lacked the chain of a necklace, too.

Pain flared, from his scar, as his fingers brushed over the engraved writing of the crown... tiara?

Snatching his hand back, he suppressed the idea of slapping it to the floor. Memories of Katie Bell sprang back to mind, and he instead slapped the wooden box closed.

His fingers itched and tingled, as he wandered on, deeper into the room. Until he found a thickly padded wing-back chair. It reminded him of the ones in the common room, though a little the worse for wear. Settling down, Harry was glad for a little privacy, peace and quiet. Free from the different demands placed on him.

Pulling a book, from his back, he gave a small snort, as 'Advanced Potion Making' came out. The tattered cover looking as fragile as ever.

https://68.media.tumblr.com/8ea6c9a93423...

Carefully folding, the cover down he traced his finger over the inscription. The faint indentation of quill scratches, a reminder of the mundane nature of the book. However, powerful and knowledgeable the previous owner.

https://68.media.tumblr.com/ad204a560765...

He flicked ahead to the next section that Professor Slughorn had told them they'd be studying. He didn't want to lose his reputation in Potions, or the chance to impress him, any leverage that could help him retrieve that memory needed to be exploited. He wasn't sure he convinced himself, but it did no harm either. He knew the book wasn't imbued with any menace itself. A test he hated to admit he was reluctant to perform.

But, both Hermione and Ginny, were finally convinced. The pages crackled dryly as he turned them. His attention caught, by an arcane swirl on the previous page. He recognised it as a wand gesture, and beneath it. Pectore cresce, was the incantation, and beneath it, for enemies (witches).

He murmured to himself, once more Hermione's suggestion, that somehow, the Prince was female. Was this a spell, only a witch could cast, or was the target only to be a witch. Wandless his finger traced the path through the air, the spell unspoken as his lips moved silently. Perhaps, it was a weaker spell, like Sectumsempra, but somehow gentler.

Distracted, Harry glanced at his wrist. The old analogue watch, a replacement to his digital one. A cheap Casio, a present from the Dursleys one Christmas. The best present he'd ever received, until he saw it had come free with some breakfast cereal. Alas, digital watches and magic didn't mix, and he'd bought something more reliable from Diagon Alley. It's face aged yellow, and with two other smaller dials at 3 o'clock and 9 o'clock, with the phases of the moon, the other being a tiny orrery, with the position of the planets.

It was almost time for his next class, easing himself up from the chair with a groan and a sigh, Harry headed off.

135.content:
Harry woke... or thought he had... looking around he only saw a forest. It was dark all around.

Lumos.

The light cast a glow around the tip of his wand. The effect was the opposite of what he wanted to achieve. It made the shadows deeper, the darkness blacker.

"It's only a dream.... It's only a dream...." he kept muttering under his breath. His recollection was fuzzy, but the last thing he could think of was being in the castle. Whatever he was thinking.... wherever his mind was, physically he was in the castle. Harry tried to picture himself slumped on the floor... tried to imagine himself getting to his feet... tried to imagine waking up.

A noise startled him, and he whirled around. The shadows danced and flickered.

"Harrrry ... Pottter..." the voice hissed. It sent a shiver down his spine. Voldemort.

"Show yourself... show yourself you coward." he snarled, spat into the engulfing darkness.

His defiance fell into the abyss, and was swallowed.

"Harrry...." the voice was at his ear, just over his shoulder.

He whirled around, almost loosing his footing in the undergrowth.

There was nobody there.

"Harrrry...." he felt the warmth of his breath tickling his ear.

He turned more slowly this time, but again Voldemort wasn't there.

"You're alone, Harry.... All alone..."

Harry's lip curled up in contempt.

"I'm not alone." the voice continued with amusement.

Something made him look upwards... It was a chilling sight, there were dementors circling above... He felt his soul grow colder, grow harder. He felt the fear of losing his Godfather afresh... he remembered losing Sirius in the ministry. Despair grew, hopelessness threatened to overpower him.

The light flickered at the tip of his wand as his grip loosened.

"Surrender... Just surrender... and let the pain end... let it all end."

The words, the sentiment were still from the Dark Lord, but Harry felt more swayed by them.

He thought of Ron and Hermione... Perhaps without him they wouldn't be targeted. He felt hope swell, as he realised that even if they weren't beside him physically, his friends hadn't abandoned him.

Expecto Patronum!

There was a flurry of white sparks, but it faded into the dark. Harry refused to surrender.

EXPECTO PATRONUM!

This time, the light shot from the tip, and the stag formed proudly it pranced around Harry. His very presence illuminating the enclosed glade more than his previous spell.

He chanced another glance upwards, the dementors were still circling, but not descending.

There was a serpentine laughter, and Harry felt his head being wrenched. A shriek was ripped from his throat. Ahead of him, a cloaked figure was fighting his patronus. There was a flash of pale skin. The hands gripped the antlers, and Harry felt the pain rip across his temple. Not merely focused on his scar.

In a shower of sparks, the antlers detached. His knees gave out, and he fell to the mossy ground.

"Oh, dear... oh deer-y deer-y me."

The forest faded, and the voice faded, as Harry felt the cold smooth stone of the castle floor reassert itself.

14.content:
He'd just left Hermione with a new pile of books in the library, and made his excuses and gone. He wasn't sure that Hermione had even noticed. Harry enjoyed just wandering the castle. In his first year, he'd found the Mirror of Erised, and that had made him always want to find more of the castles secrets.

A place as old as this, with it's history, and it's predecessors made him take a deep breath as if he could inhale their memory their deeds. He wanted to find what had made his father an animagus. Professor McGonagall always insisted that it was a rare skill, but the fact that James, Sirius and even Peter Pettigrew... were all animagi. Well, it just seemed as if there was more at play.

He tried to quiz Hagrid for clues, without giving away too much himself. He'd never come out and asked directly, although asking the Head of house didn't seem especially suspicious. So he liked to probe Minerva as much as he could. As the only animagus in the school (or at least the only registered one), he tried to be as flattering as possible.

He liked to suggest that Dumbledore was an animagus, and ask what his form was, what his patronus was...

He was lost in thought as he walked. It wasn't a corridor that was immediately familiar, but sometimes that was the way of it. Rounding a corner, he spotted Ron standing outside a door. There was something very odd, furtive about his behaviour, that stopped him from calling out to his friend.

He slipped back around the corner, and pulled out his cloak. It slid into place, and with a shimmer he was invisible. Harry was free to observe Ron's odd manner.

He was a look out... Glancing worriedly up and down at the least noise, even an unexpected breeze was enough to make Ron start to sweat and look unsettled.

A number of unpleasant ideas surface, a Slytherin curse or some kind of controlling geas. But as George and Fred burst out of the door, the reason became clearer.

There was a prank afoot.

George and Fred high fived each other, and smiled.

"They'll never discover it... until it's too late."

Ron's eyes darted between his brothers, clearly he wasn't in on the plan, as he listened intently for snippets of information, clues as to the prank.

"The Slytherin's will have a fun practice." George said before giving a ludicrously camp wink to his brother.

As Harry padded down the corridor his senses were peaked. There was a muted boom, followed by a hiss and a scattering of shouts. He looked around anxiously, his invisibility cloak would be no protection if a horde of students came barrelling down the passageway. There was a huff of escaping gas, and Harry spotted a flare of emerald smoke jetting out from behind a portrait.

It was a rather flustered looking old man. He was posed in a chair, but he kept trying to look behind his own frame. Harry backed against the opposite wall. The frame of the picture juddered, more gas burst out, the ornate frame making it dance in billowing patterns.

The cries became louder... closer.

It fell into place. Harry recognised the picture.... recognised the location. This was an entrance to the Slytherin common room. With a crash the frame gave a crack, and the picture swung aside. Out from the green smoke strode the students. Some covering their mouths, others just coughing, promising vengeance between rasping breaths.

Harry wanted to help, this seemed a cruel prank. But he stopped, revealing himself like this would make him look like the prankster. He knew there wasn't much love for him in that particular house. Harry covered his mouth, as more students came out. They milled around, and Harry was careful to avoid getting too close, to risk bumping into anyone.

There was something else that was a little odd about it. All of the Slytherin students were female. He wondered if there was a meeting for the Slytherin girls, or whether this was the Weasley's target. Until he spotted a certain platinum blonde girl.

She looked particularly upset, and offended. There was a snarl on her face, and an overbearing manner that shouted that this girl was Draco Malfoy. There was also the fact that she was drowning in a poorly fitting boys uniform.

He was glad to be covering his mouth, otherwise a harsh burst of laughter would have given him away. Harry looked closer, there was more than one girl in the wrong uniform. However, that was already altering. Hogwarts had a very strict dress code. A very strict dress code that was magically enforced.

Before Harry's eyes, Draco's trouser legs pulled up, retreating up his legs, revealing first bare ankles and soon an elegant knee. As it rose the fabric stitched itself together. He tugged at the hem, in a futile battle for dignity. The uniform showed no mercy, and soon Draco was appropriately dressed in the Slytherin girls uniform. Or so Harry thought.

With a high yelp, and a flurry of hands. Draco fought against the bra that was forming beneath her shirt turned blouse. It lifted the girls, and gave her the support and separation that she hated needing.

Despite knowing who she was, Harry still found her attractive. Her face a challenging pout, rather than a spiteful scowl. Her nose and mouth petite and delicate.

One of the girls scowled as she realised something.

"Shit. You know the rules. We still have to attend classes."

"Shit..." There was soon a chorus of unhappy muttering, some wanted to deny it, but others harder to read.

Harry recognised Pansy Parkinson, and she looked to be in her element. She goosed the arse of the new girls, each squawk making her smile wider, bearing more teeth.

"No... NO" Draco's denial was high and girlish. "But... But... I've got Quidditch Practice." he moaned. She went pale... paler even than her normal skin tone.

"So. Do you consider being a girl, a punishment." Pansy said, sneaking up behind Draco. She snaked one arm around the new girl's waist, rather low on her hip. She leaned in a licked Draco's earlobe.

Was he still a he... Harry's hands darted to his crotch... or rather her crotch.

Her hands discovered that Harry was now a member in good standing of the fairer sex. The pressure of her hands meant that Harry felt the cool embrace of satin panties, beneath her uniform. The uniform that was now approaching it's final changes.

Harry had to stop herself from just racing into the toilets. An invisibility cloak wouldn't hide a door mysteriously opening and closing. Sitting down opposite the doors to the toilets, she waited under the cloak. Already she was sure that she had a rather significant ass.

She gave a snort, a girl for less than an hour, and already thinking about how big her ass is. Harry was happy when nobody came out or entered the toilets. In fact, nobody had even walked down the corridor while Harry had sat and waited.

Her centre of balance was different, and kept her aware of the changes. Beneath the cloak, the light was diffuse and poor, but her bust was clear. Besides, her hands had already confirmed that she was the newest female student in Hogwarts.

But, this was starting to look like a good place to wait out the effects of the Weasley gas. A last glance to either side, she strode across the hall, and entered the toilets. Or would have hadn't the magic kept her out. The door flared a brilliant blue, and rippled outwards to the frame.

Apparently, the Hogwarts magic wasn't fooled by Harry's invisibility. For the moment, Harry wasn't able to enter the boys toilets. With a resigned sigh, Harry looked to her side, and spotted the girls toilets.

The door to the girls toilet offered no such resistance. The toilet was empty, without even a ghostly presence. Harry slid the cloak off, and took in her face in the mirror. The cloak gave a crackle as Harry lay it down on the counter. It had never had a manual, and he truly hoped it wasn't beyond repair.

There was no denying she was cute. Her mop of hair had grown out, the untidiness worked to create a different effect. She didn't look unkempt, weirdly it added to her appeal. She had 'just fucked' hair. Her emerald eyes were wide and inviting, her nose petite, her lips full and ruby red.

It was a very Harry-biased opinion, but she was looking at the cutest girl in the school. The thought made her smile, revealing gorgeous pearly white teeth. Harry suddenly realised the cutie in the mirror was herself, and the smile vanished.

There was even a subtle layer of make-up on her face. Tilting her head, she spotted an old friend. The scar appeared between the locks flowing over her temple. It was lighter, paler, but the shape was still clear. Anyone seeing her would see Harry Potter, if they saw the scar.

Her teeth clicked angrily, she would have to stay hidden the entire time, until this ... this thing was over. Dearly Harry hoped it would only last an hour.
